description:
Paper 59 of the Constructive Reverse Mathematics series. We formalize the p-adic precision bound N_M = v_p(det(1 − φ)) = v_p(1 − a_p + p) = v_p(#E(F_p)) for elliptic curves with good reduction. The Hasse bound a_p² ≤ 4p implies #E(F_p) ≥ 1, so N_M is always well-defined.

We verify N_M for 24 entries across 4 elliptic curves (X₀(11), X₀(14), X₀(15), 37a) at primes of good reduction. Four entries are anomalous (N_M ≥ 1); 20 are generic (N_M = 0). Maximum precision loss is N_M = 2 at X₀(15)/p=2.

Key theorems: (A) Hasse bound implies #E(F_p) > 0 (nlinarith). (B) Ordinary non-anomalous: p ∤ (1−a_p) implies N_M = 0. (C) Supersingular: a_p = 0 implies N_M = 0. All computation is pure integer arithmetic—no p-adic analysis or period rings appear.

“Axiom 5” (de Rham decidability) is a THEOREM for geometric representations: de Rham (Faltings/Tsuji) ⇒ potentially semistable (Berger) ⇒ weakly admissible (Colmez–Fontaine) ⇒ N_M computable in BISH.
